first_reasoning: We should allocate the full $10 million to the Consumer Products Division because only a bold, consumer-oriented innovation can snap us out of years of margin erosion and sales decline. By funding a high-potential concept through a disciplined stage-gate process—with early focus-group validation, cost-model checks and a cross-functional go/no-go review to confirm manufacturing, supply-chain and IP feasibility—we maximize upside while capping downside. This approach gives us the best shot at restoring growth and profitability quickly.
second_reasoning: We are allocating the entire $20 million to the Consumer Products Division because our analysis shows that only a bold, consumer‐focused innovation can turn around our decade‐long margin erosion and sales plateau. By concentrating all resources on this high‐leverage opportunity—and using a disciplined stage-gate process with early focus-group validation, cost modeling, bi-weekly IP reviews, and a cross-functional go/no-go checkpoint—we maximize the chance of a game-changing product launch while capping downside early.
